dashboard.title: Dashboard

tutorial.title: Tutorial
tutorial.desc: ðŸ“– Take a quick look at the functions of Chaos Mesh Dashboard

steps.dashboard: Dashboard is an overview of Chaos Mesh, where you can observe the running status of all experiments.
steps.workflows: Workflows manage all workflows. Here you can organize multiple experiments to simulate more realistic failures.
steps.schedules: Schedules manage all schedules. Here you can run an experiment periodically.
steps.experiments: Experiments manage all experiments, where you can perform various operations (pause, update, archive, etc.) on the experiment.
steps.events: Events show all the events generated.
steps.archives: Archives show all archived workflows, schedules, and experiments.
steps.newW: You can start your first workflow from here.
steps.newS: You can start your first schedule from here.
steps.newE: You can start your first experiment from here.
steps.search: Search provides multiple syntaxes to help you locate workflows, schedules, and experiments quickly.
steps.namespace: Browse the respective objects by selecting the different namespace.
steps.predefined: Predefined can store custom schedules and experiments for quick execution.
steps.end: ðŸŽ‰ Congratulations on completing all the tutorial steps! Click the blank space to exit.

dashboard.newbieDesc: â›‘ Quickly inject a fault from a simple experiment
dashboard.startAWorkflowDesc: Workflow allows you to organize multiple experiments to simulate more realistic failures
dashboard.startAScheduleDesc: Schedule allows you to run an experiment periodically
dashboard.predefinedDesc: ðŸ“¦ Store custom experiments here for quick execution

newE.title: New experiment
newE.byYAMLDesc: Create an experiment or schedule by filling in or uploading YAML

scope.namespaceSelectorsHelper: Specifies the namespaces to which target Pods belong.
scope.labelSelectorsHelper: Specifies the labels that target Pods come with.
scope.annotationSelectorsHelper: Specifies the annotations that target Pods come with.
scope.phaseSelectorsHelper: Specifies the phases of target Pods.
scope.modeHelper: Specifies the mode of the experiment.
scope.targetPodsPreview: Preview of Pods to be injected
scope.targetPodsPreviewHelper: Checking or unchecking Pods to further limit the scope.
scope.targetPhysicalMachinesPreview: Preview of physical machines to be injected
scope.targetPhysicalMachinesPreviewHelper: Checking or unchecking physical machines to further limit the scope.

experiments.title: Experiments
experiments.deleteDesc: You can still find this experiment in the archives
experiments.pauseDesc: You can restart the experiment in the same position
experiments.startDesc: The operation will take effect immediately

node.deadlineHelper: The node will end within the deadline. Supported formats of the deadline are: ms / s / m / h.

container.title: Container
container.commandHelper: Optional. Specifies the command running in the container, enter the string and ends Enter to create a single command.

messages.m1: Please complete the creation of the previous task first
messages.m2: Please fill in the current branch first
messages.redundant: Duplicate names detected, please create templates with unique names

basic.scheduleHelper: The schedule is expressed in the form of CronJob. If you are not familiar with it, you can use {crontabguru} to help define it.
basic.concurrencyPolicyHelper: Whether to allow experiments to run at the same time.
basic.startingDeadlineSecondsHelper: Counts how many missed jobs occurred from the value of startingDeadlineSeconds until now.

schedules.title: Schedules
schedules.deleteDesc: You can still find this schedule in the archives

workflows.title: Workflows
workflows.deleteDesc: You can still find this workflow in the archives.

archives.title: Archives
archives.deleteDesc: The Archive will be permanently deleted

debugMode.title: Debug mode
debugMode.choose: Creating an experiment doesn't send a real HTTP request, but prints the relevant information in the console.

enableKubeSystemNS.title: Allow kube-system namespace
enableKubeSystemNS.choose: The kube-system namespace is allowed to be selected in the scope when creating an experiment.

useNewPhysicalMachineCRD.title: Use new PhysicalMachine CRD
useNewPhysicalMachineCRD.choose: When creating PhysicalMachineChaos, retrieve the available PhysicalMachines instead of providing the address field.

useNextWorkflowInterface.title: Use the next generation of workflow interface
useNextWorkflowInterface.choose: Over the past period of time, we have refactored the interface related to workflows. Now you can create workflows more easily in the form of the flowchart. (Note: This improvement is still under active development and the interface is still subject to change until it is stable.)

addToken.prompt: Enter the token (RBAC Authorization) to continue
addToken.prompt2: Don't know how to get the token?
addToken.generatorHelper: ðŸ‘‡ Generate different tokens by choosing different namespaces and roles.
addToken.generatorHelper2: 1. After choosing, save below content as rbac.yaml.
addToken.generatorHelperGetTokenCase1: If you are using Kubernetes 1.24+, you need to create the token manually:
addToken.generatorHelperGetTokenCase2: Else the token is generated automatically, you can view it with:
addToken.or: Or use the following authentication methods

tip.title: Use the following syntax to quickly locate workflows, schedules, experiments and archives:
tip.namespace: namespace:default xxx / ns:default xxx will search for workflows, schedules, experiments and archives with namespace default
tip.kind: kind:NetworkChaos xxx will search for schedules, experiments and archives with kind NetworkChaos

common.durationHelper: Supported formats of the duration are: ms / s / m / h.
common.isKVHelperText: Type key:value and end with Enter to generate a key/value pair.
common.logoutDesc: You need to re-enter the token after logging out
common.name: Name

physic.addressHelper: Type and end with Enter to add one or more chaosd addresses.
